articles.headline: Beware: That In-Room Coffee Just Might Cost You
articles.snippet: Taking their lead from the airlines, hotels and resorts are raising add-on fees to record levels.
articles.abstract: Taking their lead from the airlines, hotels and resorts are raising add-on fees to record levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: As hotel fees hit record highs, even the free in-room coffee is no longer sacred.

articles.headline: Apple Is Said to Owe Back Taxes to Irish Government
articles.snippet: The potential clawback, estimated to be hundreds of millions of dollars, may stoke tensions between American and European officials over tax policies.
articles.abstract: The potential clawback, estimated to be hundreds of millions of dollars, may stoke tensions between American and European officials over tax policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union’s competition authorities are poised to announce a major tax ruling against Apple’s tax dealings with the Irish government on Tuesday, a decision that will likely increase trans-Atlantic tension over how some of the world’s largest companies pay taxes on their global operations.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and James Kanter

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Piles Up Research in Bid to Needle Donald Trump at First Debate
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s team is gathering insights into Mr. Trump’s personality to pinpoint weaknesses, but he prefers a freewheeling approach to avoid sounding “scripted or phony.”
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s team is gathering insights into Mr. Trump’s personality to pinpoint weaknesses, but he prefers a freewheeling approach to avoid sounding “scripted or phony.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s advisers are talking to Donald J. Trump’s ghostwriter of “The Art of the Deal,” seeking insights about Mr. Trump’s deepest insecurities as they devise strategies to needle and undermine him in four weeks at the first presidential debate, the most anticipated in a generation.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Endorsed on Instagram by a Kardashian, but Is It Love or Just an Ad?
articles.snippet: Companies are spending big to have celebrities praise their products to millions of social media followers, raising questions about disclosure rules.
articles.abstract: Companies are spending big to have celebrities praise their products to millions of social media followers, raising questions about disclosure rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: The millions of people who follow Kim Kardashian West and her sisters on social media have become accustomed to seeing them praise everything from fat-burning tea to gummy vitamins for healthier hair.

articles.headline: Israel Quietly Legalizes Pirate Outposts in the West Bank
articles.snippet: Unauthorized settlements dot hilltops in the West Bank, and anti-settlement groups and Palestinians say retroactively legalizing them is a methodical effort to change the region’s map.
articles.abstract: Unauthorized settlements dot hilltops in the West Bank, and anti-settlement groups and Palestinians say retroactively legalizing them is a methodical effort to change the region’s map.
articles.lead_paragraph: MITZPE DANNY, West Bank — One night in the fall of 1998, a self-professed “outpost entrepreneur” brought three trailers to a rugged hilltop in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and established his first pirate settlement.

articles.headline: How 12 EpiPens Saved My Life
articles.snippet: People with food allergies hope to never use an EpiPen, but sometimes we don’t have a choice.
articles.abstract: People with food allergies hope to never use an EpiPen, but sometimes we don’t have a choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: I used my first EpiPen at the age of 7, after eating chocolate cake at a restaurant, sliced with the same knife used on a walnut cake.

articles.headline: Apple Owes $14.5 Billion in Back Taxes to Ireland, E.U. Says
articles.snippet: The decision by the European commissioner for competition ramps up trans-Atlantic tensions over how much companies with global operations should pay to countries where they do business.
articles.abstract: The decision by the European commissioner for competition ramps up trans-Atlantic tensions over how much companies with global operations should pay to countries where they do business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union on Tuesday ordered Ireland to collect $14.5 billion in unpaid taxes from Apple, a record penalty that worsened tensions with the United States over the bloc’s crackdown on sweetheart deals with global multinationals.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Mark Scott
